reviews.review_text: Pre-emptive warning: I haven't spoiled any major plot points, but there are some tonal spoilers for one of the game's endings.  I err on the side of recommending this game, but I can't claim that it isn't very deeply flawed. Its main failing is that the story is about a lot of things, but the ending is 100% reliant on whether or not you 'win back' your love interest. Personally, I thought it would be most satisfying to play a character initially very deeply set on reconnecting with his ex, but gradually coming to terms with the breakup and, in the end, letting the ceremony go uninterrupted. In this playthough, I had been successful in almost every aspect of my life: religiously keeping a journal, participating only in activities I believed in, and treating everyone with kindness. My character's future was promising. So, what ending did I get?   The one where I'm suicidal, nihilistic and alone because I couldn't bear the pain of losing my ex-girlfriend, who I'd had every intention of getting over on the way to her wedding. This is the only ending possible if you fail to 'win her back', regardless of your other achievements or the way you've roleplayed your character. The game as a whole could be massively improved by the removal of the framing device at the beginning and end, as, for many endings, it fundamentally doesn't make sense and stands contrary to the story's themes. There's a fine post-credits scene, but it didn't negate my confusion at my character's hysterical response to making a perfectly fair, mature decision that, in my mind, caused him no great pain. It was a very 'Huh?' moment for me.   As for the rest of the story, it's pretty good. Extremely tonally uneven (I found myself going 'Really?' probably a dozen times) but not at all bad when you look past that, and I genuinely enjoyed most of the campaign. The trip was gruelling but satisfying, with more than its share of close calls and poignant moments, and it felt like I was coming to the end of a long journey when I finally arrived at the ex's wedding location. It's not realistic, but there's a realness to it -- something humbling about the situations you're faced with, an earnestness in the way the game presents love, friendship, and hope. I guess that's why I felt degraded by the ending... I mean, how can my character be so nihilistic when the past month has probably been the most interesting in his life? He's learned so much, experienced so much, yet the game gives me a pitch-black failstate because I didn't adhere to the arbitrary goal. It's not only unsatisfying, but also troubling philosophically. I guess I would recommend this game with the cliche that you should focus on the journey, not the desitation... or play with the LI in mind. Either way.

Few games manage to tell such a breathtaking story with such admirable minimalism as Always Sometimes Monsters does. What’s even greater is you are in control of the story, and how the game will pan out. For me, calling this a game is an understatement of what it really is. Always Sometimes Monsters is a declaration about life, about how our choices are all we really have, and about how those choices, no matter how small, can reorient our life in ways that we can never predict. In life there is regrets, happiness, anger, wishfulness and countless other human feelings. Always Sometimes Monsters shows that while experiencing these feelings is inevitable, you will never be able to travel back and reshape your life with different choices, so you have to make the best of what you have and never sink into regret with the decisions you’ve made in life, or you will never be able to move forward in the unique journey that is your life. 10/10

Always Sometimes Monsters   is a slice-of-life story about a down-on-their-luck writer determined to travel across the country to win back their ex, who is to be married in a month. Always Sometimes Monsters is definitely worth a playthrough.

Early on in the game I save-scummed for money by getting all winning $50 scratch cards and winning constantly at rock-paper-scissors. 'Haha!' I told the game, 'I am beating your system and successfully keeping my character from ever doing anything monsterous or ending up in too bad a position!'  Then I realized that it was me all along. The person always sometimes being a monster was me as the player gaming the system to give my character a good pool of money she wasn't supposed to have to dip into. So I went 'Well then, let me be evil!' and outright used Cheat Engine to give myself thousands of dollars, because if I was going to feel like the game was judging me for my actions I might as well go all out!  I'm recommending the game because it has a well-written story that kept me interested until the end, but let you warn you going in that it can be a slog. The game is full of unpleasant characters and situations that always try to go worse for your character. Even if you try to keep your hands as clean as you possibly be can a good hunk of the game characters will still treat you like dirt (although, to be fair, that is realistic for folks who are trying to turn their lives around after hitting rock bottom). And if you try to keep your funds up the honest way you'll quickly find that the minigames you do for work are dull as ditchwater, in a deliberate commentary on how mindnumbing minimum-wage jobs can be by the developer. Don't play this unless you don't mind a story that treats you like that! But for me personally I found it a fun challenge to try to hunt down (in most cases just having money isn't the answer, my cheatiness mostly just kept me from having to do unpleasant things for food) the 'good' choices through any given scenario when they weren't spelled out for you, and I imagine that other people would have an equally fun time seeing just how monstrous they could become!

I will admit to having never written a review before but this game was so good that I simply couldn't not.  Always Sometimes Monsters delivers what it promises. It gives an experience where, based on race, gender and sexuality, your experiences change. However, this isn't all it provides. The story itself is gripping and amazing, with lots of different paths and lots of different consequences for your actions. I will admit that the story is somewhat stream-lined in that it's city to city to city, with fixed cities, however there is still plenty of room for diverging paths. On top of this, it provides an experience where you're often wondering whether or not you will be able to get through it; not because the game's that hard, but because the story twists in so many ways. On top of this, it also has some interesting moments when characters delve into philosophy.  There are some cons however, the first being the potential for grinding. I'll give you an example. I was in a factory, loading boxes, told I could keep going until I was finished. The counter is 2 digited, so I assumed it wouldn't be too many. I loaded 101 boxes before giving up, with no indication that there was an end or not. As well as that, the jobs can be a bit boring/monotonous, but I suppose that's part of the game so I can't judge it for that. Also, I whilst I found Easter Eggs winking at the fourth wall clever, the heavy-handedness of this at the end was not to my taste.  All in all, a fantastic game, indicated by the fact I'm going in for my second run now.

First of all, I want you to know: I do NOT think that this is a game for everybody. I myself am still a bit torn on what to think about it. I love the idea and the execution is...fine but not flawless in my opinion. I think it's best I list a view points that could be of interest to potential buyers (NO spoilers!): - my first playthrough took me about 9h30min - you can't create your own character by choosing what they look like but you have several different characters (and significant others) to choose from at the beginning of the game - the story and characters are what drives the game - you really should be someone who enjoys these 'choose your own adventure' kind of games - you should also be someone who's into these kinds of stories (about ordinary people and their daily struggles mixed in with a sappy love story) - the gameplay itself gets rather repetitive after a while - besides some mini-games (which range from being kinda fun to annoying), you will spend a lot of time walking and talking - the game has a high replayability if you care enough about the characters and story to make you wanna see all the different outcomes and paths As there are so many different paths to play, you might want to consider checking out a playthrough on Youtube or so if you are still unsure on whether to buy the game or not. Might give you a good idea about the game's atmosphere which you really should get into if you hope to have a good time playing. So all in all, I decided to recommend this game as I love these types of story-driven, choice-making games in general and commend the developers for giving a game like this a chance. And once again: I think that if you can get into the story and characters enough, it'll make up for gameplay and you'll have a good time seeing how you're character's story unfolds.

Coming from a background of someone that loves sim games, I honestly didn't know what to expect with Always Sometimes Monsters. In the beginning of the game, it felt really weird and I felt as though the game didn't know which genre it wanted to be. After getting past the introduction; however, that is where the real drama happens and I was pleasantly surprised by how great the quality of the narrative is.  Basically, you are trying to get to the wedding of your ex in the next 30 days, but you are broke and have no family or any other means to help you get to where you need to go. Fufilling jobs, getting favors, and doing side missions, all the while keeping your stamina needs up are key to winning the game. There's also a choice system as well, and depending on your actions, you can change the ending of the game.   Honestly, Always Sometimes Monsters felt as though I was binging a Netflix series. The game is just beautiful in terms of how immersive the storyline can be. I made myself the main character and my partner as the ex and things got real pretty quickly!   Also, I have to give the creators a round of applause for allowing not only interracial relationships but also same sex relationships as well.   Pros: +Excellent narrative with real customization options to make the story your own. +Game play that really keeps you on edge, clock ticking anxiety makes it exhilarating.  +Mini-games are really fun and quite symbolic to life as well. +The soundtrack is really good! Very memorable soundtrack.  Cons: - The choice sections come up really fast. I wish there was a delay or something before the choices come up, because there has been numerous occasions where I would hit the space bar to progress dialogue and accidentally make a choice that I didn't want to make!!! Please somehow fix that!  Overall, I would most definitely reccomend Always Sometimes Monsters. I just finished the game and I'm still emotional at the ending I got. Definitely worth the time and money. It's like reading an interactive book. Highly, highly recommended!

Before I get into the review, I will try to spoil as little as poosible about the story. There will some MINOR SPOILERS, but I will mostly refer to the begining of the game, but ever so vague. Well, let us begin :)  Story: You are a character that has his/her life is in shambles and loses his/her boyfriend/girlfriend after the prologue of the game. Soon enough, you recieve an invitation to your ex's wedding ceremony that will occur in 30 days. It is your job to go get your ex back. Or is it?   Graphics: It's pixel art so what do you expect? Kidding aside, it suits the game quite nicely in my opinion.   Music: I love the music so much. Many songs will repeat, but you will never get tired of it, at least I didn't.  Gameplay: I did not say this before, but this game will not appeal to everyone because all you practically do is read. I see this game more as a Visual Novel rather than a game to be honest, but it is a really good one at that. There is a lot of text in the game, but with good reason. This game is all about choice. A lot of games that are out now have 'choices' in them, but this has to be the best game to deliver choice thus far in my opinion (Yes I have played Mass Effect 1-3 and Witcher 1-2 and I love them both if that means anything). Every choice you make, whether it being in dialogue or in action, it carries weight. What I love even more are that these choices are very subtle. There is no moral meter, light/dark, or red/blue. All of the choices are grey and does not have a big sign showing 'Make big decision here!!'  There are also various minigames to play to break the reading which are actually quite fun.   Pros: +Story +Music +Gameplay  +CHOICES  Cons: -Gameplay (I put it here twice because there is a lot of reading, but it didn't bother me)   In all, I had a great time playing the game. I believe that it was worth the $10 (got it for $9 though). The story is very engrossing and can sometimes give you the feels. In the end, we are Always Sometimes Monsters. Do you object taking a reward or do you take more than what someone says you can take? Do you stab someone in the back to get ahead or let your own life crumble to make someone else happy? The game often asks those kind of questions and expects you to answer. If you can accept that not every story has a happy ending then you probably can embrace this game cause chances are you probably won't get the 'Good Ending' on the first try but if you keep trying you should be able to. I don't write a whole lot of reviews, but I felt this game absolutely deserved one more Steam recommendation.  Always Sometimes Monsters is a fine example of an indie game made with heart but moreover an exempliary case of a story rich, content driven game. (Not that the graphics were bad for the retro sort of style. And the music was really good too!) Despite the risk of sounding tacky I'd describe ASM as a deep dive into the wide spectrum of humanity and life. It was funny, sad, clever, delightfully philosophic, beautiful, simple in a complex way - and genuinely thought-provoking at times. Regardless of the medium, I do enjoy stories and anecdotes that make the gamer/viewer/user reflect some element of their own life, perhaps questioning it or, on the other hand, feeling reassurance over it. Or maybe just cause that, either warm or melancholic, 'Yeah, I can relate' feeling.  The freedom of choice contributed to a great atmosphere throughout and I found myself quickly immersed each time I played. Also, unlike in other multiple-choice-type games I decided not to reload and replay each fork on the road and opted to just flow with it instead. It felt right not to see what might've been and instead just experience it uniquely as it happened - kinda like going through life itself.  As someone who dabbles with writing stories as their dear hobby, I must say: hats off to the developers for their vision and unique approach! Video game experiences like this are few and far between! I consider Always Sometimes Monsters a good story, good game, and definately an experience worth recommending!

This can be a very good game, depending on how you play it, as it is a very choice based game, and it's not just the ending that is affected by your choices, your gameplay is as well. This game has very varying gameplay, very great character choices, but it can be quite confronting.  Sometimes when you play the game you will be faced with a difficult choice, and what you choose will not only affect the storyline of the game, but also the gameplay. So for example, if you choose to work in a tofu factory instead of a meat factory for temp work. If you work in the meat factory you will get more money, which will help massively in the rest of the game, but the gameplay will be a lot more boring, as you cannot leave until work is finished. But in the tofu factory you can leave anytime you want, so if you get bored of the gameplay, you can leave, but you get less money overall, which may affect your game. Also making a choice may also affect your morality. If you make a 'good' decision, as opposed to an 'evil' decision, things will turn out very differently. If you deicde to do something, it might mean you cannot do another thing. You might end up missing out on oppitunities and experiences. So experiences require you to do boring tasks, while other require you to do exciting and interesting things. It's really up to you.  The character choices are quite good. You are allowed to play as a homosexual couple, an interracial couple or a heterosexual couple. Obviously you will experience different things depending on what you pick. The game will even let you be transgender! This is very important if you want to have your character as close to yourself as possible, or if you want to try and understand the situtation that others are in. It will not make you completely understand the complexity of another person's mind and experiences, but it will at least give you a chance to empathise. Having a character that it like yourself will (in my case at least) make you feel closer to the character and become more involved in the story.   Despite all this great stuff, the game is quite confronting in many places. This can be seen as a good or a bad thing. It can be seen as a good thing to make an impact and to get you more emotional about the story/game, but it can also make you feel very uncomfortable to play. If it does make you feel uncomfortable, it is just a game, that you can turn off, and leave for as long as you want, before you can continue playing again (if you wanted to continue playing). The game has some slurrs mixed in to the dialogue, and some harsh statements as well, they don't come up extremely often, but often enough to make a bit of an impact. I have probably not experienced all the harsh statments myself, as I have not done that many playthroughs, but be warned that if you pick a gay couple, a woman, or a person of colour, you might run into some slurrs and/or harsh words, so to avoid confrontation I guess you could play as a straight, white couple and a man, but don't feel obliged to. Outside of the character choices, you will still hear some words, but not as often.  This is a pretty good game, not just in the basics of the characters, the dialogue and the choices, but it is quite beautiful, even with the style. It also has some pretty good music. The storyline is the classic 'must get my lover back', but you can also choose to just ignore them and focus on yourself. The only big problem with it is how tedious it is to start a new game, as you need to click through a lot of text boxes at the start, but it can also be quite fun to replay, as there are so many ways to play the game.

I don't think there has ever been such a realistic game on the human condition. Do we do what is best for others, or do we do what is best for ourselves? Do we allow our own personal prejudices to govern our lives, or do we listen to our heart, regardless of circumstance?  Always Sometimes Monsters casts you into the role of whoever you want to be: straight, gay, lesbian, racist or not racist. If you are a fan of getting very involved in a character's story, down to every decision they make that ultimately decides the course of their fate, then this game is for you.Do you do what is morally right, or do you do whatever it takes to satisfy your personal needs, selfish or immoral as they may be? As with many games of this genre, the 'gameplay' is more or less a vehicle to your personal choices of how you decide your character should react in a given situation. There is walking to and from locations, there are even little minigames spattered throughout the story, but none of these quite embody what this game is truly about: choice. Choices that are seen as shades of gray, not black or white. Everything you do has a consequence, but it's relative to your personal view of what is 'right' or 'wrong'.  The fact the game exudes this quality, on minimal animation and somewhat restricted graphics, is nothing short of amazing. I've spent the past 8 hours playing through one possible outcome of this tale, and all throughout I knew I could have taken the story in a different turn of events. And the thing is, the whole experience was ENJOYABLE. Always Sometimes Monsters is one part Choose Your Own Adventure and one part Life Sim coated in a often-times hard hitting and (a)morally grey love story. Your choices begin right from the start with the most unique character generation I've seen in a game in a very long while. You choose not only your character, but your character's love interest from a wide pool of character models that include various ethnicities and genders. And yes, you can pair your character with a member of the same sex. Elegantly implemented inclusion. Your choice of character model and their partner have minor effects on dialogue and how people see you--but for the most part it seems options and conversations pan out relatively the same. Note: I've only done one complete play through as a white woman involved in a lesbian relationship.   Most of the traditional gameplay you'll find is contained within short mini-game segments that range from complete cake walk to incredibly frustrating--boxing mini-game, I'm looking at you. These mini-games only serve to supplement the CYOA story, and are brief interludes. The various jobs you can choose to do in order to earn enough money to accomplish your immediate goals can also be considered mini-games, though they are little more than menu procedurals and repetitive tasks--don't expect to have a burning passion to do these jobs for any longer than you have to, which is the whole point. The jobs are a means to an end, both to the player and their character.  The game's greatest strength is its story and offering the player options to choose their own path through the narrative. As with all CYOA stories--and the same could be said about most video games--the game only has a few set paths for you to take that lead to one of a few endings. You shouldn't expect the freedom of an open world, but you should look forward to a deep story about choice and humanity you can pick your way through. Many of the choices you'll be presented with will be binary choices, but whether one choice is horrible and the other decent and reasonable is left up to the player to parse out for themselves. What the games does well is packaging many of these choices in such a way that the options available may not be readily stated, but are allowed by the system should you chose to go that route. Your more questionable choices will be called out later in the story and choosing to regret those choices or feeling justified in what you did considering the circumstances is up to you--the game does not pass down authoritarian judgment. I have some gripes about some of the choices to be made and the fairness of those outcomes, but that wanders far into spoiler territory, but let it said there will be some scenes where the consequences for your actions could not be seen beforehand and it may seem unfair. The game seeks to tries to not be judgmental of the player's choices, but at the same time has its own agenda to push--which may or may not be okay with some folks.   During my first play through I didn't get the ending I thought I was heading toward, but upon reflection of the choice I made through the game and through establishing my character's backstory through some key choices, I understood why I ended up where I did. While extremely bittersweet, I couldn't deny the effect the story I had chosen for myself had on me. I am currently going through the game a second time, wanting to give my character the ending that they deserve. I am running into content that I missed out on in my first play through because of the choices I made then. The game at least warrants two play throughs.  The story and choices aren't without their heavy-handed moments. Early on the choice of temp job you have is between working at a slaughterhouse and a soy processing plant. The game actively tries to make you feel bad for killing the pigs, but throws in the incentive that you'll make more money quicker, but with a limited run. The soy processing plant will make you money more slowly, but if you have the patience to stomach it, you could make more money than you would at the slaughterhouse. There's a commentary on sustainability in there somewhere, but I digress.  If you're looking for a story that will dive deep into the underbelly of humanity and make you consider questions of choice and desperation and love, Always Sometimes Monsters provides an incredible experience. What it may lack in relative freedom, within the confides of its system and its Choose Your Own format Monsters provides a tightly crafted and satisfying feels inducing experience worth the price of admission.

This is a thought provoking, original, well written, incredibly human game with a lot of subtle humour that really reflects on its own nature. I was positively surprised by it. You're down on life, your love has left you, and you know nothing as certain as that you have to get her back. So you go on a long, sometimes brutal journey to reach him/her, making ethical decisions on the way, deciding how to make the days count. The game can at times be slow, but it gripped me from the start with its writing. Events happen frequently and keep the pace just fine. I honestly cared for some of the characters and found myself sometimes going back to a previous safe just in order to amend a bad decision I made. Although I imagine going with your guts at first and sticking to them is also really great in this game. And probably makes more sense for what the developers intended.   Here your choices really give the impression of mattering, and you have a large impact on the lives of the other characters in the story. Be good, be bad, you can be always a monster, sometimes a monster - you get the idea.   Can really recommend this game. Worth several playthroughs I reckon, because one playthrough is definitly not enough to see all the options there could be if you had only done something different. Always a few other people to side with, or other decisions to make that determine how you feel about the person you made the character become in the end.  Ending is probably a bit deterministic. From what I can see so far there is about three or four different endings, but they dont necessarily rely too much on all the things you have decided during the journey. I enjoyed the ending nonetheless, although it wasn't the best written part in the story. Something a character in the story says comes to mind 'are you prepared for your happy ending?' well we might not even want it. Or something like that.  Anyway. Graphics are charming. Music stays in the head but is always well fitting. Few minigames to break the old mold, some of them pretty fun. Real interesting concept. Can recommend wholeheartedly.

I am usually a fan of games that are thought provoking with branching and complex storylines, as well as ethical decisions that affect the world around you. There were some points where the game was very enjoyable and others where it taught be something about my own morals (pretty straight, but willing to hose the people who try to cheat me). And I enjoyed how the creators were meta, and stuck themselves in the game. And some points were pretty hilarious, like when I broke into a doctor's mansion to recover evidence of his teddybear fetish for blackmail.  Unfortunately, there were many points in the game where I was unsure of what to do. I would spend a good half hour or more wandering around town trying to find something, ANYTHING to do to pass the evening so they game would FINALLY let me start a new day. Othertimes it was very redundant. Don't get me wrong, it was hilarious to get a job butchering pigs ALL DAY LONG... but when I've got to do that for three days in a row, it got pretty dull. I guess work is work, and that's reflective of real life. But in the end I felt it sort of forced my hand. As recommended, I named the main character after me, and the ex after my ex. But I really had no desire to travel across country to go to her wedding. I mean, inviting me to her wedding? That was a 'dickish' thing to do. I'd rather work hard and get my life back on track... But butchering pigs was pretty dull, so in the end I bought a bus ticket, just so I could pull out a little more entertainment out of this game. Because there was literally NOTHING else I could do at that point.  I also wasn't a huge fan of a lot of the dialogue. There was a lot of swearing, trash talking, etc that detracted (I felt) from the game. Maybe that's just me, but it felt overused. Also some of the dialogue and cut scenes were... long and without much substance. Maybe that's another way this game tried to mirror real life. But sometimes I felt myself skipping through scenes, thinking 'I really need a break, but I HAVE TO SAVE MY GAME!' 15 minutes later, I finally get a chance to save.  I really hate to say I don't recommend this game. You can tell a lot of thought and effort went into it. It's only $10, and a lot of people really enjoy it. You might really enjoy it too. Who knows? Maybe it's worth taking the chance. But for me, it wasn't worth the investment.

ASM is a game made in RPGmaker, which already earns it negative points because RPGmaker is an awful engine, that is all about your choices, expect not really. Wedding happens, I let the girl go so she can get married, and yet despite me saying repeatedly that I did not want to get back with my LI, I turn out to become a bum because she was my TRUE LUV and without her, despite the fact that I could easily get a job and find someone else, I'm just a useless sack of ♥♥♥♥. I was excited to play this game when I first saw it appear on the Steam store. It looked like it was going to be a thought-provoking, deep experience where people would be able to compare the different choices that they had made and the outcomes that resulted from them. I was wrong.  Though on a first playthrough it is easy to believe that the choices that you are making change the story, a second playthrough (or even a bit of research) quickly prove otherwise. At best your choices make a minor difference that lasts about as long as the next scene. At worst, there is literally no difference at all. Once you discover that the choices in the game don't matter all that much, your second realization is that the story is rather bland as well. I'll avoid discussing the ending for the sake of those who are reading this review but still wish to give the game a chance but I definitely suggest not getting your hopes up.  As far as the story goes, there were several parts that entertained me and (while still having the belief that choices affected the narrative in a major way) seemed promising. On the opposite side of that, there was plenty in the game that drained the fun out of it. The vast majority of the jobs in the game were an absolutely terrible grind. This makes it so that earning money is less of side quest and more of 'you know, I think I'm going to skip eating today' moment. Call that realism if you'd like, though I prefer to enjoy myself the entire time that I'm playing a game.  Overall, the game was okay up until the discovery of an extremely linear storyline and downright bad after it. It had potential to be a great game if the developers had put a little more heart into it.

It's strange the game that I don't like, but I can say that Always Sometimes Monsters is one of those, if you happen to be reading this before you've completed the game and still aren't hooked with it, do yourself a favor and stop playing, I kept going thinking it would get better and it just didn't. The game is LOOOONG and for bad gameplay reasons, since the story is relatively short, issues like movement and dialogue speed make the game feel sluggish, there are some nice story beats every now and then but ultimately they fail to deliver.  The game promises a choice driven experience which is completely false, your decisions are inconsequential until the final moments of the game in which it boils down to the traditional choice structure that you've seen in a million other games.  I have to give credit where its due, the game starts with promise when choosing the main character and the love interest, but it falls short just a couple of hours into the game when it becomes a snorefest of doing chores and getting X amount of money to get Y or doing X thing for Y to get something in return (which usually translates to money or quest items).  The humor wasn't to my liking, some people may be into it but it felt pretty immature and cheessy. I would also have liked an option to get over your love interest, the whole story hinges on the presumption that the player wants to get back the ex, since there is no way to make your character get over him/her, this makes him/her (i.e. your character) feel unidimensional, stupid, and boring.  Also the game developers appear on the game, their inclusion felt like it didn't fit at all and they wanted to give themeselves a semi-important part on the game, appearing on every single city and even on the epilogue, they felt out of place in the game and the wall-breaking wasn't to my taste.  I can see what they (i.e. the developers) were trying to achieve with this but I felt ike they didn't succeed , nevertheless there are some good ideas which could be rescued and I'd like to see them expanded like documenting a journey or dynamic character interaction based on your main character, so I'll be looking forward to the next game they make, but if possible I'd skip their first stab at accomplishing their vision.  I seriously can't recommend this game there are many other things I didn't like but most of the reviews I've read also cover those issues I had with the game (e.g. save scumming, bad endings all around, incoherent story, dumb stamina system, etc.), if you're planning to play a similar game with a great story and even developed on the same engine I'd recommend playing To the Moon, both your time and money would be invested better in that game.

The writing didn't express the author's intent as much as it did the characters moral values which were always extremely black and white. There is a difference between a  sad  story and a  depressing  story.  After a sad story we feel catharsis. We feel like we've explored an idea, like we've walked in another person's shoes. Sure, the story didn't turn out well, but not everything in life does. We can learn from it. Sad stories serve a purpose.  A  depressing  story, on the other hand, tells us nothing we don't already know. Life sucks. Work is boring and unfulfilling. Society is cruel and unfair. Damn near nobody cares about us; they're all out to get their own. Connections we make in our lives are all the more precious for being freaking rare, and we have to treasure the few good things we have for the limited time we still have them.  We know all that.   After experiencing a sad story, you feel cleansed. After experiencing a depressing story, you want 1.4 hours of your life back.  Judging by my rating, in which category do you think I place this ridiculous runaround of a game?  I guess someone who's had a much easier life than mine might find a game like this eye-opening. Honestly, though, it's so far removed from reality anyway that it can't even be instructive.
